awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Ethnographic Study of Local-level Policy Implementation Diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award looks at how national, state, and local policies, discourses, and people interact to produce a local service choice environment.  Policy development may assume a direct translation from the objectives developed at federal and state levels to implementation and response at the community level.  But the United States comprises a great diversity of local contexts. This research addresses the important question of how that diversity affects policy implementation.

The research will be conducted by anthropologists Sarah B. Horton (University of Colorado at Denver) and Whitney L. Duncan (University of Northern Colorado). The researchers have chosen to focus on local perceptions of health care service availability as a case study of policy devolution. They will undertake a comparative, longitudinal investigation of how specific residents in two different sites in Colorado, one urban and one rural, connect with and understand the availability of health care services for chronic diseases. Policies are standard across the state but are mediated by different local institutional, historical, and sociocultural contexts. The goal is to see what difference those contexts make. Working cooperatively with local clinics, they will collect data through interviews and participant observation with local stakeholders, patients, and health care staff. They will also analyze local media accounts and relevant documents. Findings from this research will be valuable for policy makers, service providers, and service users. The research will also enrich social scientific understanding of the complex functioning of the contemporary state and the different ways in which citizenship is made concrete at the local level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This ethnographic study examined the impacts of local, state, and federal policies on Colorado-based Latinx immigrants' health, well-being, and sense of belonging in the nation. Using a longitudinal and multi-method approach, the study explored how discourses, practices, and experiences of deservingness unfolded over time in conjunction with policy changes and changes in participants' communities and lives. The COVID-19 pandemic began 1.5 years into the study; the research therefore investigated how both pre-existing and pandemic-era policies contributed to immigrants' ability to seek healthcare and navigate a protracted public health crisis.

The research revealed that specific policies--such as the proposed 'public charge' rule change, the longstanding exclusion of many immigrants from health and unemployment insurance, and their more recent exclusion from stimulus payments and other forms of emergency assistance during the pandemic--negatively impacted research participants' senses of safety, well-being, and belonging in the nation during the study period. On a material level, exclusionary federal and state policies contributed to participants' economic marginalization, impeded their ability and willingness to seek healthcare, and contributed to disproportionate sickness and economic strife during acute phases of the pandemic. On a symbolic level, such policies contributed to subjective experiences of fear and distress and in some cases eroded participants' trust in institutions and state support systems. At the same time, inclusive local policies, programs, and organizations helped mitigate such harms. The study also revealed how the pandemic's fallout provoked participants' assertions of self-worth and sociopolitical projects of belonging and mutual care. These findings help advance anthropological and social scientific understanding of how federal, state, and local constructions of health citizenship interact to mediate the material and symbolic dimensions of immigrants' health-related deservingness.

Broader Impacts: This project helps improve the well-being of Latinx immigrants by revealing the multi-level factors that encourage or discourage participation in health care, community incorporation, and sense of inclusion in the nation. Thus far the research has yielded multiple policy briefs shared with elected officials, community members, and policy committees; editorials, public-facing blog posts, and media interviews centered on improving access to healthcare for immigrants; and ten professional presentations. The PI has shared the research results--particularly on barriers to healthcare; COVID-19 testing, treatment, and vaccines; and Emergency Medicaid--with local community-based organizations, clinic chains, human services agencies, and health departments. Participant interviews also helped identify issues that prevent immigrants from applying for economic and rental assistance programs for which they qualify; the PI helped immigrants navigate such resources and provided program administrators feedback on the barriers that immigrant applicants face. In sum, as the pandemic has significantly impacted immigrants' ability to seek health care, economic stability, and health, the project has yielded data that will help guide local, state, and federal policy on how best to support immigrant community members. Additionally, the project funded multiple positions for Latinx-identifying, Spanish-speaking undergraduate students to work as research assistants, thus providing valuable research training experiences for underrepresented students. 


Last Modified: 01/17/2023
Modified by: Whitney L Duncan
